snippet.textDisplay:
Ruiz is the biggest waste of talent in boxing. On his best days, he will be a big problem for ANY of the top boys today - as AJ found out. Holyfield is one of the greatest fighters of all time. He sparred with Ruiz for 4-5 weeks, and said he would usually break fighters down, then bust them up, but Ruiz was relentless - he just kept coming, and I couldn't break him down...."I realised that he was the man I couldn't beat, so I knew I had to get out of the game before his time came..."

When you get a great like Holyfield making honest statements like that on camera, you KNOW there's a world champion there - he has the ability, but just lacks the mental discipline and desire to stay at the top. If your going to take a place in history, you have a very short window in boxing to decide how good it will be, so you may as well give it your all. Sadly, Ruiz may well go down as the man who got lucky against Joshua instead of being recognised as a great heavyweight - it's only you that can change it Andy.

snippet.textDisplay: RUIZ WOULD RUIN WILDER.
snippet.textOriginal: RUIZ WOULD RUIN WILDER.

snippet.textDisplay:
Deontay Wilder was misled to believe he was the "Baddest Man On The Planet" because his one punch concussive power took out guys who were not Prime Level Boxers.
Please do not misunderstand me. His previous opponents were all good fighters but they were not highly skilled and physically gifted professionals like the boxer he fought last week. While it is true he knocked down that same boxer 15 months ago twice, I cannot believe he and his team could give that a great deal of credibility considering that opponent was 400 pounds a year earlier and had just overcome drug and alcohol addiction.
I also cannot believe they thought they could knockout a 275 pound boxer who is also nimble with just a total of a couple punches in the rematch. What world were they living on? They simply did not anticipate the obvious even though it was right in front of them.
Team Fury openly stated what they planned to do prior to the rematch and that Wilder would see a different version of Fury. Yet Wilder and his team totally dismissed it. They thought that Wilder's increased size would be enough to counter anything Fury had to offer as they simply did not expect their bigger opponent to be as aggressive as he turn out to be.
Team Wilder believed the hype of his invincibility as they openly stated their contempt to learn the "Sweet Science"! "Who needs skills when you got power?" is a direct quote from Deontay Wilder. That is virtually the same as stating "Who needs intelligence when you got power?" His team of "Yes Men" supported that.
I did not care for Fury's rough house tactics. However, he did in such a manner so that it would not draw the attention of the referee, who is only supposed to penalize blatant infractions. Just conceive that in a 55 mph road, you are driving 59 mph. Legally speaking, you are speeding but it is not blatant enough for a police officer to pull you over and issue you a ticket. What Fury did was analogous to that.
I actually supported Wilder for obvious reasons. He is an American from the South fighting a foreigner, a Brit of Irish Gypsy descent.
However, the fact that Wilder is still a country bumpkin was his total undoing. Tyson Fury has been in boxing since age 5. He has been surrounded himself with the boxing elites from all over the world in the last 20 years. He was trained by late Emmanuel Steward and then his uncle Peter Fury, who still is regarded as one of the best coaches in the world. He was then trained by a future great Ben Davison, who is an already outstanding conditioning coach., and now finally Javan Steward.
Javan "Sugar Hill" Steward manages Kronk's Gym, which is known for improving the knock out proficiency of their boxers. Yet country bumpkin Wilder could not see the "Coming of the Storm."
While Wilder is truly naive, Fury despite his antics is very crafty and sophisticated. Why do you think he did the WWE match in Saudi Arabia and actually received training in professional wrestling?
While extra money and raising his profile with the American market are always nice, the primary reason for this decision was to become more mentally and physically aggressive. Of course he utilized some of the WWE tactics in his rematch against Wilder.
However, Fury has always been a defensive fighter who pedals on his backfoot a lot. For him to change his underlying philosophy, he had to change his fundamental mentality.
Training and doing WWE was an excellent and innovative way for him to achieve this.
Wilder is going to undergo a crisis of confidence. This is to be expected. Please watch the posted video clip and see if you cannot determine parallels and similarities.
Wilder was thoroughly beaten by Fury from start to finish. His flush shot on Fury's chin bounced off like bullets of Superman's chest. Even in the 2nd round, where he outpointed Fury, the impact that Fury punches and his leaning had on Wilder was clearly taking a toll.
In the first Ruiz-Joshua bout, Ruiz only won two of the seven rounds convincingly: the 3rd and 7th. In the 3rd, Ruiz was actually knocked down before he scored two knockdowns. In the 7th, his opponent went down twice but that was mainly due to exhaustion as his legs were totally sapped. It was not at all due to the severity of Ruiz's punches.
In all 7 rounds of Wilder-Fury 2, Fury punches against Wilder exacted a severe impact.
One of Wilder's managers, Shelly Finkel, recently stated he protected Wilder throughout his career in subtle but clear manner. Despite having nearly 30 fights under his belt, Finkel let it slip that he did not want Wilder to fight either the Ukrainian Klitschkos because he was not ready. Guess what? Fury snuck in and seized the belts from Wladmir Klitschko in 2015.
Despite UK's Anthony Joshua and his promoter Eddie Hearn begging Wilder for the undisputed unification bout with Wilder, his team has repeatedly dodged them. Wilder's team even recently turned down a 120 million USD from them.
Why will Team Wilder not allow Wilder fight AJ? Because they know that AJ would be the first championship caliber fighter Wilder has ever faced. Wilder caught Fury after a three year layoff and still managed only a draw.
A top caliber fighter, Dillian Whyte of the UK, has been ranked the No. 1 WBC challenger to Wilder's belt for two years. He has been clamoring for his chance and has been denied. He was bypassed twice in 2019 in favor of Breazeale and Ortiz!
In Wilder's first bout against a championship caliber boxer, he got totally manhandled. Unfortunately his team deceived Wilder and fed his ego. Their protection caused Wilder to crash. In 44 fights, Wilder is going to question his previous victories and wonder why he was prevented from fighting the best?
Stupidity is often defined as doing the same thing and expecting a different result. If Wilder does the same thing with the same team in training, he will get the same beatdown in the trilogy.
Wilder will be fighting someone who is bigger, stronger, more technically sound, and has better footwork than him. He was foolish to think that the fact he gained 22 pounds from his last bout against Fury was going to be a deciding factor. First of all, gaining weight does not increase power. Secondly, he would still be 40+ pounds lighter than his opponent so bulking up is not really going to be a positive factor. Finally, that extra weight will serve more of a disadvantage for Wilder as he will lose stamina more quickly, especially when he is being "leaned on" a lot in the clinches. Clinches also always tire a bigger fighter less.
Wilder had the same power for the rematch than he did in their first bout. He obviously was stronger for the rematch but he still will lose a match with a fighter who weighs significantly more than him if leaning, grabbing, and pushing are factors. For Wilder to win the trilogy, he must lose weight and he must avoid getting grabbed and lean on.
Deontay Wilder has less than 5 months to fight the trilogy. He need to hire a trainer such as Anatoly Lomachenko, who coaches Oleksandr Usyk.
Wilder needs to fight Usyk-style. That constant movement that style employs is the only way Wilder can defeat Fury. Wilder must continuously circle Fury and throw punches as he moves in order to drain the nervous energy of Fury.
Usyk, training for a fight, stays only with his staff. He sleeps in a wooden bed and stays in a barn. Wilder needs to do the same thing. He needs to train in a remote ice village in the Ukraine. If Wilder stays away from the comforts of home as Fury did for the rematch, Wilder could very well win the trilogy.
If he continues to train in his hometown with his current team, this trilogy match will be the swansong for the "Hamma From Bama"! Any Questions?

Team Fury openly stated what they planned to do prior to the rematch and that Wilder would see a different version of Fury. Yet Wilder and his team totally dismissed it. They thought that Wilder's increased size would be enough to counter anything Fury had to offer as they simply did not expect their bigger opponent to be as aggressive as he turn out to be.
Team Wilder believed the hype of his invincibility as they openly stated their contempt to learn the "Sweet Science"! "Who needs skills when you got power?" is a direct quote from Deontay Wilder. That is virtually the same as stating "Who needs intelligence when you got power?" His team of "Yes Men" supported that.
I did not care for Fury's rough house tactics. However, he did in such a manner so that it would not draw the attention of the referee, who is only supposed to penalize blatant infractions. Just conceive that in a 55 mph road, you are driving 59 mph. Legally speaking, you are speeding but it is not blatant enough for a police officer to pull you over and issue you a ticket. What Fury did was analogous to that.
I actually supported Wilder for obvious reasons. He is an American from the South fighting a foreigner, a Brit of Irish Gypsy descent.
However, the fact that Wilder is still a country bumpkin was his total undoing. Tyson Fury has been in boxing since age 5. He has been surrounded himself with the boxing elites from all over the world in the last 20 years. He was trained by late Emmanuel Steward and then his uncle Peter Fury, who still is regarded as one of the best coaches in the world. He was then trained by a future great Ben Davison, who is an already outstanding conditioning coach., and now finally Javan Steward.
Javan "Sugar Hill" Steward manages Kronk's Gym, which is known for improving the knock out proficiency of their boxers. Yet country bumpkin Wilder could not see the "Coming of the Storm."
While Wilder is truly naive, Fury despite his antics is very crafty and sophisticated. Why do you think he did the WWE match in Saudi Arabia and actually received training in professional wrestling?
While extra money and raising his profile with the American market are always nice, the primary reason for this decision was to become more mentally and physically aggressive. Of course he utilized some of the WWE tactics in his rematch against Wilder.
However, Fury has always been a defensive fighter who pedals on his backfoot a lot. For him to change his underlying philosophy, he had to change his fundamental mentality.
Training and doing WWE was an excellent and innovative way for him to achieve this.
Wilder is going to undergo a crisis of confidence. This is to be expected. Please watch the posted video clip and see if you cannot determine parallels and similarities.
Wilder was thoroughly beaten by Fury from start to finish. His flush shot on Fury's chin bounced off like bullets of Superman's chest. Even in the 2nd round, where he outpointed Fury, the impact that Fury punches and his leaning had on Wilder was clearly taking a toll.
In the first Ruiz-Joshua bout, Ruiz only won two of the seven rounds convincingly: the 3rd and 7th. In the 3rd, Ruiz was actually knocked down before he scored two knockdowns. In the 7th, his opponent went down twice but that was mainly due to exhaustion as his legs were totally sapped. It was not at all due to the severity of Ruiz's punches.
In all 7 rounds of Wilder-Fury 2, Fury punches against Wilder exacted a severe impact.
One of Wilder's managers, Shelly Finkel, recently stated he protected Wilder throughout his career in subtle but clear manner. Despite having nearly 30 fights under his belt, Finkel let it slip that he did not want Wilder to fight either the Ukrainian Klitschkos because he was not ready. Guess what? Fury snuck in and seized the belts from Wladmir Klitschko in 2015.
Despite UK's Anthony Joshua and his promoter Eddie Hearn begging Wilder for the undisputed unification bout with Wilder, his team has repeatedly dodged them. Wilder's team even recently turned down a 120 million USD from them.
Why will Team Wilder not allow Wilder fight AJ? Because they know that AJ would be the first championship caliber fighter Wilder has ever faced. Wilder caught Fury after a three year layoff and still managed only a draw.
A top caliber fighter, Dillian Whyte of the UK, has been ranked the No. 1 WBC challenger to Wilder's belt for two years. He has been clamoring for his chance and has been denied. He was bypassed twice in 2019 in favor of Breazeale and Ortiz!
In Wilder's first bout against a championship caliber boxer, he got totally manhandled. Unfortunately his team deceived Wilder and fed his ego. Their protection caused Wilder to crash. In 44 fights, Wilder is going to question his previous victories and wonder why he was prevented from fighting the best?
Stupidity is often defined as doing the same thing and expecting a different result. If Wilder does the same thing with the same team in training, he will get the same beatdown in the trilogy.
Wilder will be fighting someone who is bigger, stronger, more technically sound, and has better footwork than him. He was foolish to think that the fact he gained 22 pounds from his last bout against Fury was going to be a deciding factor. First of all, gaining weight does not increase power. Secondly, he would still be 40+ pounds lighter than his opponent so bulking up is not really going to be a positive factor. Finally, that extra weight will serve more of a disadvantage for Wilder as he will lose stamina more quickly, especially when he is being "leaned on" a lot in the clinches. Clinches also always tire a bigger fighter less.
Wilder had the same power for the rematch than he did in their first bout. He obviously was stronger for the rematch but he still will lose a match with a fighter who weighs significantly more than him if leaning, grabbing, and pushing are factors. For Wilder to win the trilogy, he must lose weight and he must avoid getting grabbed and lean on.
Deontay Wilder has less than 5 months to fight the trilogy. He need to hire a trainer such as Anatoly Lomachenko, who coaches Oleksandr Usyk.
Wilder needs to fight Usyk-style. That constant movement that style employs is the only way Wilder can defeat Fury. Wilder must continuously circle Fury and throw punches as he moves in order to drain the nervous energy of Fury.
Usyk, training for a fight, stays only with his staff. He sleeps in a wooden bed and stays in a barn. Wilder needs to do the same thing. He needs to train in a remote ice village in the Ukraine. If Wilder stays away from the comforts of home as Fury did for the rematch, Wilder could very well win the trilogy.
If he continues to train in his hometown with his current team, this trilogy match will be the swansong for the "Hamma From Bama"! Any Questions?

snippet.textDisplay: For all the people that are talking about him sweating, I’m on a TV show and I’ve been under the lights they use in studios,  they can be hot if they aren’t LEDs. Not saying he wasnt sweating from the weight but those lights are a factor. He also could have been training that week, you never know.
snippet.textOriginal: For all the people that are talking about him sweating, I’m on a TV show and I’ve been under the lights they use in studios,  they can be hot if they aren’t LEDs. snippet.textDisplay: I think Andy lost so much of the goodwill that people had for him after the first fight by not showing up in shape on the second fight. All the money that people spent on flying over and for the PPV of that fight and he let everybody down. He's in danger of becoming a joke figure unless he takes it seriously. I hope he gets back in shape and comes back. A third fight with AJ is certainly winnable, but I'd doubt he will be given that opportunity.
snippet.textOriginal: I think Andy lost so much of the goodwill that people had for him after the first fight by not showing up in shape on the second fight. All the money that people spent on flying over and for the PPV of that fight and he let everybody down. He's in danger of becoming a joke figure unless he takes it seriously. I hope he gets back in shape and comes back. A third fight with AJ is certainly winnable, but I'd doubt he will be given that opportunity.

snippet.textDisplay: The thing is every fighter he beat could have beaten him. They were just scared from majority validation of what his one styled fighting could do. If they quit from being chickens and not be having replays of wilders fights in their head while in the ring with him, they could have ate him up. He capitalized on their fears. He knew they were half beat before the fight no matter the fake persona they put up. This time fury wasn’t having it.
